title: China Eximbank provides RMB 291 million government concessional loan for Phase 3 of National Road Improvement Project (Linked to Project ID#42210, #64185, #64929)
description: On December 22, 2009, the Chinese Government and the Government of Tonga signed an RMB 291 million preferential loan framework agreement for Phase 3 of the National Road Improvement Project. Then, on January 22, 2010, China Eximbank and the Government of Tonga signed an RMB 291 million (or TOP 94 million or $44.2 million) government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for Phase 3 of the National Road Improvement Project. The GCL carried the following borrowing terms: a 2% interest rate, a 5.1666 year grace period, a 20.1666 year maturity, a 1% management fee, and a 0.75% commitment fee.    The loan achieved an initial disbursement rate of 30% due to requirements for a (lump sum) down payment by one of the contractors responsible for implementation. The remainder of the loan was disbursed on a quarterly basis.   The loan's amount outstanding was TOP 25,072,560 as of June 30, 2010, TOP 46,005,821 as of June 30, 2011, TOP 72,093,767 as of June 30, 2012, TOP 86,281,500 as of June 30, 2013, TOP 98,823,600 as of June 30, 2015, TOP 96,786,600 as of June 30, 2016, TOP 93,934,800 as of June 30, 2017, TOP 101,704,504 as of June 30, 2018, TOP 101,762,700 as of June 30, 2019, TOP 97,692,857 as of June 30, 2020, and TOP 86,252,400 as of June 30, 2021. The borrower made a TOP 854,377 repayment (TOP 854,377 in interest and TOP 0 in principal) between July 1, 2009 and June 30, 2010, a TOP 1,007,716 repayment (TOP 1,007,716  in interest and TOP 0 in principal) between July 1, 2010 and June 30, 2011, a TOP 1,241,133 repayment (TOP 1,241,133 in interest and TOP 0 in principal) between July 1, 2011 and June 30, 2012, a TOP 1,576,251 repayment (TOP 1,576,251 in interest TOP 0 in principal) between July 1, 2012 and June 30, 2013, an unknown repayment between July 1, 2013 and June 30, 2014, an unknown repayment between July 1, 2014 and June 30, 2015, TOP 2,060,807 repayment (TOP 2,060,807 in interest and TOP 0 in principal) between July 1, 2015 and June 30, 2016, a TOP 2,103,674 repayment (TOP 2,103,674 in interest and TOP 0 in principal) between July 1, 2016 and June 30, 2017, TOP 2,009,008.29 repayment (TOP 2,009,008.29 in interest and TOP 0 in principal) between July 1, 2017 and June 30, 2018, a TOP 1,971,116.65 repayment (TOP 1,971,116.65 in interest and TOP 0 in principal) between July 1, 2018 and June 30, 2019, a TOP 6,626,171 repayment (TOP 1,958,738 in interest and TOP 4,667,433 in principal) between July 1, 2019 and June 30, 2020, and no repayment of principal or interest between July 1, 2020 and June 30, 2021.   The purpose of Phase 3 was to improve the Alipate Road in the suburb of Kolomotua on the island of Tongatapu, the road from Kolonga to Talasiu on the island of Tongatapu, and the road from Haveluliku to Lavengatonga on the island of Tongatapu.   China Civil Engineering Construction Corporation and Yanjian Group were the contractors responsible for implementation. A formal groundbreaking ceremony took place on January 22, 2010. Phase 3 was officially completed and handed over to the local authorities on March 7, 2011.   However, this project was controversial in that it contributed to debt sustainability problems for the Government of Tonga. According to a Joint IMF/World Bank Debt Sustainability Analysis that was published in 2011, the combined face value of the RMB-denominated China Eximbank loan for the Nuku'alofa Central Business District (CBD) Reconstruction Project (captured via Project ID#37646) and the RMB-denominated China Eximbank loan for Phase 3 of the National Road Improvement Project (captured via Project ID#39199) was equivalent to 30% of Tonga’s GDP. Then, In May 2012, the IMF published a report which concluded that ‘Tonga remains at a high risk of debt distress based on the joint IMF-WB low-income country debt sustainability assessment (LIC DSA). Scheduled repayments on the two loans … from the China EXIM Bank may pose a fiscal challenge unless sufficient cash reserves are built up by improving tax collections and reining in current expenses. [The Government of Tonga’s] balance sheet also faces a currency risk as about 61 percent of the outstanding external debt is denominated in Chinese renminbi.’ Due to concerns about Tonga’s level of public debt exposure, the repayment terms of the China Eximbank loan for Phase 3 of the National Road Improvement Project were rescheduled (through a 5-year grace period extension) in 2013 (as recorded in Project ID#64929). As as result of the rescheduling, the borrower agreed to make semi-annual principal repayments between March 21, 2020 and March 21, 2030
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the Tonga Highway Upgrade and Reconstruction Project. The Chinese project title is 揽的汤加道路改造工程（三期优贷项目) or 援汤加主岛公路升级改造三期工程项目.2. The Chinese Government also funded Phase 1 and Phase 2 of the National Road Improvement Project (see Project ID#42210 and ID#64185).3. The borrowing terms of the loan are drawn from the World Bank's Debtor Reporting System (DRS). See https://www.dropbox.com/s/2sw4f7gluxa52fk/DRS%20Official%20Commitments%20from%20China%20Through%202021.xlsx?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/ab8qt4n6jijcbhd/IDS_Average%20interest%20on%20new%20external%20debt%20commitments.xlsx?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/949n5rctiue6d7c/IDS_Average_grace_period_and_maturity_on_new_external_debt_commitments.xlsx?dl=0
combined_text:
# Sector
TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

# Title
China Eximbank provides RMB 291 million government concessional loan for Phase 3 of National Road Improvement Project (Linked to Project ID#42210, #64185, #64929)

# Description
On December 22, 2009, the Chinese Government and the Government of Tonga signed an RMB 291 million preferential loan framework agreement for Phase 3 of the National Road Improvement Project. Then, on January 22, 2010, China Eximbank and the Government of Tonga signed an RMB 291 million (or TOP 94 million or $44.2 million) government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for Phase 3 of the National Road Improvement Project. The GCL carried the following borrowing terms: a 2% interest rate, a 5.1666 year grace period, a 20.1666 year maturity, a 1% management fee, and a 0.75% commitment fee.    The loan achieved an initial disbursement rate of 30% due to requirements for a (lump sum) down payment by one of the contractors responsible for implementation. The remainder of the loan was disbursed on a quarterly basis.   The loan's amount outstanding was TOP 25,072,560 as of June 30, 2010, TOP 46,005,821 as of June 30, 2011, TOP 72,093,767 as of June 30, 2012, TOP 86,281,500 as of June 30, 2013, TOP 98,823,600 as of June 30, 2015, TOP 96,786,600 as of June 30, 2016, TOP 93,934,800 as of June 30, 2017, TOP 101,704,504 as of June 30, 2018, TOP 101,762,700 as of June 30, 2019, TOP 97,692,857 as of June 30, 2020, and TOP 86,252,400 as of June 30, 2021. The borrower made a TOP 854,377 repayment (TOP 854,377 in interest and TOP 0 in principal) between July 1, 2009 and June 30, 2010, a TOP 1,007,716 repayment (TOP 1,007,716  in interest and TOP 0 in principal) between July 1, 2010 and June 30, 2011, a TOP 1,241,133 repayment (TOP 1,241,133 in interest and TOP 0 in principal) between July 1, 2011 and June 30, 2012, a TOP 1,576,251 repayment (TOP 1,576,251 in interest TOP 0 in principal) between July 1, 2012 and June 30, 2013, an unknown repayment between July 1, 2013 and June 30, 2014, an unknown repayment between July 1, 2014 and June 30, 2015, TOP 2,060,807 repayment (TOP 2,060,807 in interest and TOP 0 in principal) between July 1, 2015 and June 30, 2016, a TOP 2,103,674 repayment (TOP 2,103,674 in interest and TOP 0 in principal) between July 1, 2016 and June 30, 2017, TOP 2,009,008.29 repayment (TOP 2,009,008.29 in interest and TOP 0 in principal) between July 1, 2017 and June 30, 2018, a TOP 1,971,116.65 repayment (TOP 1,971,116.65 in interest and TOP 0 in principal) between July 1, 2018 and June 30, 2019, a TOP 6,626,171 repayment (TOP 1,958,738 in interest and TOP 4,667,433 in principal) between July 1, 2019 and June 30, 2020, and no repayment of principal or interest between July 1, 2020 and June 30, 2021.   The purpose of Phase 3 was to improve the Alipate Road in the suburb of Kolomotua on the island of Tongatapu, the road from Kolonga to Talasiu on the island of Tongatapu, and the road from Haveluliku to Lavengatonga on the island of Tongatapu.   China Civil Engineering Construction Corporation and Yanjian Group were the contractors responsible for implementation. A formal groundbreaking ceremony took place on January 22, 2010. Phase 3 was officially completed and handed over to the local authorities on March 7, 2011.   However, this project was controversial in that it contributed to debt sustainability problems for the Government of Tonga. According to a Joint IMF/World Bank Debt Sustainability Analysis that was published in 2011, the combined face value of the RMB-denominated China Eximbank loan for the Nuku'alofa Central Business District (CBD) Reconstruction Project (captured via Project ID#37646) and the RMB-denominated China Eximbank loan for Phase 3 of the National Road Improvement Project (captured via Project ID#39199) was equivalent to 30% of Tonga’s GDP. Then, In May 2012, the IMF published a report which concluded that ‘Tonga remains at a high risk of debt distress based on the joint IMF-WB low-income country debt sustainability assessment (LIC DSA). Scheduled repayments on the two loans … from the China EXIM Bank may pose a fiscal challenge unless sufficient cash reserves are built up by improving tax collections and reining in current expenses. [The Government of Tonga’s] balance sheet also faces a currency risk as about 61 percent of the outstanding external debt is denominated in Chinese renminbi.’ Due to concerns about Tonga’s level of public debt exposure, the repayment terms of the China Eximbank loan for Phase 3 of the National Road Improvement Project were rescheduled (through a 5-year grace period extension) in 2013 (as recorded in Project ID#64929). As as result of the rescheduling, the borrower agreed to make semi-annual principal repayments between March 21, 2020 and March 21, 2030
justification: Project focuses on road improvement without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Improvement of Alipate Road, Kolonga to Talasiu road, and Haveluliku to Lavengatonga road; no mention of renewable energy or environmental components

title: China donates computer equipment to the Parliament of Tonga
description: On February 10, 2010, Fan Guijin, the Chinese ambassador to the Kingdom of Tonga, signed a handover document with the Speaker of the Tongan parliament, in Nuku'alofa, the capital of Tonga. The handover document was for a donation made by The Standing Committee of the National People's Congress of China to provide a group of computer equipment, including desktop computers, notebooks, printers and photocopiers, to the Kingdom of Tonga Parliament.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
China donates computer equipment to the Parliament of Tonga

# Description
On February 10, 2010, Fan Guijin, the Chinese ambassador to the Kingdom of Tonga, signed a handover document with the Speaker of the Tongan parliament, in Nuku'alofa, the capital of Tonga. The handover document was for a donation made by The Standing Committee of the National People's Congress of China to provide a group of computer equipment, including desktop computers, notebooks, printers and photocopiers, to the Kingdom of Tonga Parliament.
justification: Project involves donation of computer equipment to government institution without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation of computer equipment to Tongan Parliament, no energy-related components mentioned

title: Hanban provides Chinese instructor from the Confucius Institute for University of West Indies [linked #39706]
description: On Dec. 12, 2010, a Memorandum of Agreement was signed to send two Chinese language and culture instructors from the Confucius Institute of the People's Republic of China(or HANBAN) to the University of West Indies (UWI) St. Augustine Campus. According to the MOA, HANBAN will provide two Chinese instructors to teach Chinese language at UWI from January 11, 2011 to December 31, 2014. Only one Chinese lecturer was actually sent and the program completed at the designated date.
combined_text:

According to the MOA, HANBAN will provide two Chinese instructors to teach Chinese language at UWI from January 11, 2011 to December 31, 2014. title: Chinese Government dispatches 19th medical team to Jendouba, Sidi Bouzid, and Tunis (Linked to Project ID#35605, #14020, #35604, #35603, #12970, #31082, #35585, #56660, and #56661)
description: Since 1973, the Chinese Government has been dispatching medical teams to Tunisia. The Jiangxi Province is responsible for sending the teams. On May 17, 2010, the Chinese Government and the Government of Tunisia signed an agreement to dispatch the 19th Chinese medical team to Tunisia. The medical team consisted of 45 members team, including 8 members from the 18th medical team. It was stationed at Jendouba regional hospital (Hôpital Régional De Jendouba or المستشفى الجهوي بجندوبة), Sidi Bouzid regional hospital (Hôpital Régional De Sidi Bouzid or المستشفى الجهوي بسيدي بوزيد), and Mongi Slim Hospital (Hôpital Mongi Slim or مستشفى المنجي سليم) in the northern suburbs of Tunis. It completed its two-year term of service between October 2010 and 2012.
staff_comments: This project is linked to project ID#35605, #14020, #35604, #35603, #12970, #31082, #35585, #56660, and #56661, which are the 14th, 15th, 16th, 17th, 18th, 20th, 21st, 22nd, and 23rd medical teams sent from 2000-2019.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government dispatches 19th medical team to Jendouba, Sidi Bouzid, and Tunis (Linked to Project ID#35605, #14020, #35604, #35603, #12970, #31082, #35585, #56660, and #56661)

# Description
Since 1973, the Chinese Government has been dispatching medical teams to Tunisia. The Jiangxi Province is responsible for sending the teams. On May 17, 2010, the Chinese Government and the Government of Tunisia signed an agreement to dispatch the 19th Chinese medical team to Tunisia. The medical team consisted of 45 members team, including 8 members from the 18th medical team. It was stationed at Jendouba regional hospital (Hôpital Régional De Jendouba or المستشفى الجهوي بجندوبة), Sidi Bouzid regional hospital (Hôpital Régional De Sidi Bouzid or المستشفى الجهوي بسيدي بوزيد), and Mongi Slim Hospital (Hôpital Mongi Slim or مستشفى المنجي سليم) in the northern suburbs of Tunis. It completed its two-year term of service between October 2010 and 2012.
justification: Project is focused on healthcare services without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Dispatching medical teams, healthcare services at hospitals

title: Chinese Government dispatches youth volunteers to Tunisia
description: On January 19 and 21, 2010, the Chinese Government and the Government of Tunisia signed an exchange of letters detailing that Chinese youth volunteers would come to Tunisia. The Tunisian Government then ratified this agreement on November 15, 2010 via Decree n° 2010-2961. Tunisia's Ministry of Foreign Affairs was responsible for the implementation of this decree.
combined_text:
# Sector
UNALLOCATED/UNSPECIFIED

# Title
Chinese Government dispatches youth volunteers to Tunisia

# Description
On January 19 and 21, 2010, the Chinese Government and the Government of Tunisia signed an exchange of letters detailing that Chinese youth volunteers would come to Tunisia. The Tunisian Government then ratified this agreement on November 15, 2010 via Decree n° 2010-2961. Tunisia's Ministry of Foreign Affairs was responsible for the implementation of this decree.
justification: Project involves youth volunteer exchange program with no clear environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Youth volunteer exchange program, no energy or infrastructure components mentioned

title: Standing Committee of the National People's Congress donates office equipment to the Tunisian Chamber of Deputies (Linked to Project ID#56693)
description: On April 30, 2010,  the Economic and Commercial Counsellor of the Chinese Embassy in Tunisia and the Director of the Office of the Speaker of the Tunisian House of Representatives signed a handover certificate for the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress of the People's Republic of China's donation of office equipment to the Tunisian Chamber of Deputies. The equipment had been presented to Tunisia in March 2010, during the visit of Wang Zhaoguo, a member of the Politburo of the Chinese Communist Party and the vice chairman of the Standing Committee. Wang's visit also included a donation of office equipment to the Tunisian Chamber of Advisors, as captured by linked project ID#56693.
staff_comments: For coding purposes, AidData has used the handover certificate as the start and end dates, even though the donation was physically provided earlier.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
Standing Committee of the National People's Congress donates office equipment to the Tunisian Chamber of Deputies (Linked to Project ID#56693)

# Description
On April 30, 2010,  the Economic and Commercial Counsellor of the Chinese Embassy in Tunisia and the Director of the Office of the Speaker of the Tunisian House of Representatives signed a handover certificate for the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress of the People's Republic of China's donation of office equipment to the Tunisian Chamber of Deputies. The equipment had been presented to Tunisia in March 2010, during the visit of Wang Zhaoguo, a member of the Politburo of the Chinese Communist Party and the vice chairman of the Standing Committee. Wang's visit also included a donation of office equipment to the Tunisian Chamber of Advisors, as captured by linked project ID#56693.

title: Standing Committee of the National People's Congress donates office equipment to the Tunisian Chamber of Advisors (Linked to Project ID#56692)
description: On May 10, 2010, the Economic and Commercial Counsellor of the Chinese Embassy in Tunisia and the Director of the Public Service Department of the Tunisian Chamber of Advisors signed a handover certificate for the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress of the People's Republic of China's donation of office equipment to the Tunisian Chamber of Advisors. The equipment had been presented to Tunisia in March 2010, during the visit of Wang Zhaoguo, a member of the Politburo of the Chinese Communist Party and the vice chairman of the Standing Committee. Wang's visit also included a donation of office equipment to the Tunisian Chamber of Deputies, as captured by linked project ID#56692.
staff_comments: For coding purposes, AidData has used the handover certificate as the start and end dates, even though the donation was physically provided earlier.The source does explicitly state that the Standing Committee was the source of donation, but since Wang Zhaoguo presented the office equipment provided by the Standing Committee to the Tunisian Chamber of Deputies in March at the same time he presented the equipment for the Chamber of Advisors, AidData has assumed the Standing Committee was the source of both donations.

title: Chinese Government restructures an interest-free loan by allowing for repayment with exportable commodities
description: On December 14, 2010, the Government of China and the Government of Tunisia signed an exchange of letters on the use of goods by Tunisia to repay interest-free loans owed to China. Under the terms of this agreement, the Chinese Government allowed the Tunisian Government to repay an interest-free loan that it previously contracted - and which had entered into the repayment period - with domestically produced exportable commodities.
staff_comments: It is unclear what specific interest-free loan this debt restructuring referred to.
combined_text:
# Sector
ACTION RELATING TO DEBT

# Title
Chinese Government restructures an interest-free loan by allowing for repayment with exportable commodities

# Description
On December 14, 2010, the Government of China and the Government of Tunisia signed an exchange of letters on the use of goods by Tunisia to repay interest-free loans owed to China. Under the terms of this agreement, the Chinese Government allowed the Tunisian Government to repay an interest-free loan that it previously contracted - and which had entered into the repayment period - with domestically produced exportable commodities.
justification: Debt restructuring agreement with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Restructuring of interest-free loan repayment terms using exportable commodities

title: China donates thousands of books to Turkish educational institutions and think tanks
description: On October 18, 2010, China's State Council Information Office presented several thousands books about Chinese politics, economy, culture and history as gifts to Turkish think tanks and educational institutions amid China's efforts to boost cultural communication with Turkey. The Ankara-based International Strategic Research Organization, Middle East Technical University, Ankara University and Jale Tezer College each accepted nearly 1,000 books. The books cover such subjects as literature, religion, economy and Chinese language education and record the long history and current development of China.   The book presentation was part of the large-scale cultural event "Experience China in Turkey" held in Ankara and the Turkish city Istanbul. Aimed at promoting cultural communication and people's mutual understanding, the event covers nine major programs, such as the Chinese-Turkish political and economic forums, Chinese movie and television weeks, Chinese cuisine festival and exchanges between journalists and writers.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
China donates thousands of books to Turkish educational institutions and think tanks

# Description
On October 18, 2010, China's State Council Information Office presented several thousands books about Chinese politics, economy, culture and history as gifts to Turkish think tanks and educational institutions amid China's efforts to boost cultural communication with Turkey. The Ankara-based International Strategic Research Organization, Middle East Technical University, Ankara University and Jale Tezer College each accepted nearly 1,000 books. The books cover such subjects as literature, religion, economy and Chinese language education and record the long history and current development of China.   The book presentation was part of the large-scale cultural event "Experience China in Turkey" held in Ankara and the Turkish city Istanbul. Aimed at promoting cultural communication and people's mutual understanding, the event covers nine major programs, such as the Chinese-Turkish political and economic forums, Chinese movie and television weeks, Chinese cuisine festival and exchanges between journalists and writers.
justification: Project focuses on cultural exchange and education without direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Book donation to educational institutions, cultural communication focus, no energy-related components

title: Bank of China provides buyer’s credit loan for 2×600 MW Atlas Iskenderun Thermal Power Plant Project
description: In 2010, the Bank of China signed a buyer’s credit loan agreement with Atlas Enerji Üretim A.Ş. — a special purpose vehicle and a wholly-owned subsidiary of Diler Holding S.A. (a private company) — for the 2×600MW Atlas Iskenderun Thermal Power Plant Project. Its face value and borrowing terms are unknown. The buyer’s credit loan was insured by Sinosure. The Turkish government also issued a sovereign guarantee.  The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower to finance a $680 million EPC contract with China National Aero-Technology Import and Export Corporation (CATIC) and China Power Investment Power Engineering Company Ltd (CPIPEC). The purpose of the project was to construct a 1,200-megawatt (MW) coal-fired power plant (with two, 600 MW power generating units) in the İskenderun 1st Organized Industrial Zone (OSB) near the village of Azganlık, which is located with İskenderun district and Hatay province.  The plant was designed to supply power to two steel plants that are also operated by Diler Holding: Diler iron and steel plant and Yacizi Iron and Steel plant. The project was financed and implemented on an independent power project (IPP) basis.   Hubei Construction (湖北省工业建筑集团有限公司), CATIC (or AVIC International or 中航国际), CPIPEC (中电投电力工程有限公司), Atlas Energy, and Elektrik Üretim A.Ş were all involved in project implementation. In December 2008, Atlas Enerji Üretim A.Ş. received environmental permits to build the power plant.  The power was later suspended due to investment issues and it relaunched in 2010. Construction began on November 10, 2011. The first 600MW unit was commissioned in August 2014 and the second 600MW unit was commissioned in December 2014. The power plant achieved its commercial operation date (COD) on December 19, 2014.
staff_comments: 1. The Atlas Iskenderun Thermal Power Plant Project is also known as the 2×600MW Super Critical Coal-Fired Iskenderun Power Plant Project or Atlas 2x660MW Super Critical Coal-Fired Power Plant Project. The Chinese project title is 中航国际土耳其阿特拉斯电站项目 or 阿特拉斯燃煤电站 or 土耳其阿特拉斯超临界燃煤发电项目.2. The face value of the buyer's credit loan is unknown. For the time being, AidData assumes that it is equivalent to 85% of the $680 million EPC contract. This issue warrants further investigation.
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
Bank of China provides buyer’s credit loan for 2×600 MW Atlas Iskenderun Thermal Power Plant Project

# Description
In 2010, the Bank of China signed a buyer’s credit loan agreement with Atlas Enerji Üretim A.Ş. — a special purpose vehicle and a wholly-owned subsidiary of Diler Holding S.A. (a private company) — for the 2×600MW Atlas Iskenderun Thermal Power Plant Project. Its face value and borrowing terms are unknown. The buyer’s credit loan was insured by Sinosure. The Turkish government also issued a sovereign guarantee.  The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower to finance a $680 million EPC contract with China National Aero-Technology Import and Export Corporation (CATIC) and China Power Investment Power Engineering Company Ltd (CPIPEC). The purpose of the project was to construct a 1,200-megawatt (MW) coal-fired power plant (with two, 600 MW power generating units) in the İskenderun 1st Organized Industrial Zone (OSB) near the village of Azganlık, which is located with İskenderun district and Hatay province.  The plant was designed to supply power to two steel plants that are also operated by Diler Holding: Diler iron and steel plant and Yacizi Iron and Steel plant. The project was financed and implemented on an independent power project (IPP) basis.   Hubei Construction (湖北省工业建筑集团有限公司), CATIC (or AVIC International or 中航国际), CPIPEC (中电投电力工程有限公司), Atlas Energy, and Elektrik Üretim A.Ş were all involved in project implementation. In December 2008, Atlas Enerji Üretim A.Ş. received environmental permits to build the power plant.  The power was later suspended due to investment issues and it relaunched in 2010. Construction began on November 10, 2011. The first 600MW unit was commissioned in August 2014 and the second 600MW unit was commissioned in December 2014. The power plant achieved its commercial operation date (COD) on December 19, 2014.
justification: Primary purpose is coal-fired power generation, which is environmentally harmful and inhibits energy transition
evidence: 1,200 MW coal-fired power plant, two 600 MW coal power generating units, designed to supply power to steel plants
